STARTER: What kind of music do you usually listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience you remember?
text:
[Starter]: What kind of music do you usually listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience you remember?
[Student]: Its always been one of my favorites for the band which Im sure will keep out of it in a minute just before we meet up on that point in history The band were playing on Telegram Rock but their new album Highway Songs as they called it now was not at all popular because of its unusual sounds and melodies such as tween your body when theyre singing songs but its different instruments are still alive today and very much like those with modern music on them
[Teacher]: which might seem hard to believe but they were well ahead of its time as we say and as we say and they are very much like many of the bands of today which is a very strange thing that we often forget and we forget that they were also known for being one of the most popular bands of the past decade with over 10 million fans worldwide and are considered to be one of the most influential bands of all time and one of the most successful bands in history with over 40 million records sold and it is still hard for me to believe that they were also known for being one of the most popular bands of the past decade with over 10 million fans worldwide and are considered to be one of the most influential bands of all time and one of the most successful bands in history with over 40 million records sold so it is very strange to think that they are now gone and they would have been great to see live but unfortunately they have been gone for a very long time and it is very hard to believe that they are not around today. We are a band in the future and we are a band in the time of the past. We are a band in the future, we are a band in the music of the past, in the music

STARTER: Have you been on any trips recently? Where did you go, and did anything interesting happen there?
text:
[Starter]: Have you been on any trips recently? Where did you go, and did anything interesting happen there?
[Student]: I saw a little boy once who was so proud of his new suit that he had the appearance of an angel by mistake And he looked up at Nathalies smiling face with sparkling eyes and then glowed triumphantly as she said You are fortunate to be alive again She paused in dismay for answer as they were passing some one through the hall to sayOh
[Teacher]: my god what is he? He was a little boy with a big smile on his face and a new suit on, but he was covered in soot and ash and looked like he had been dragged through the fire. Nathalies looked at him with her usual calm demeanor and saidI know him. He is my son. (Said to be from the book "Eclipse" by Stephenie Meyer)   I have been on many trips recently.  We went to the beach for a week, and it was amazing.  We stayed in a beautiful house with a big backyard that had a pool and a hot tub.  It was so nice to be able to swim and relax in the sun.  One day, I went on a walk along the beach and saw a group of dolphins playing in the waves.  It was so cool to see them up close like that.  They were jumping and splashing in the water, and it was like they were putting on a show just for me.  I felt like I was a part of their world, and it was an incredible experience.  We also went on a boat tour and saw some really beautiful coral reefs and sea turtles.  It was amazing to see all the
[Student]: boats swimming about so slowly looking out over the top of the rocks and in the air that made such a sensation almost impossible for our boat passengers as I found myself on deck and ready to paddle out into the currents which would fill the waters with foam and spray before us across the river even if we should never reach its shores again
[Teacher]: .   I have been on many trips recently, but I have also learned some valuable lessons from my travels.  One of the most important lessons I learned was the importance of staying hydrated.  On our first day at the beach, I didn't drink enough water, and I ended up feeling really dehydrated.  It was a pretty miserable experience, but it taught me to always drink plenty of water, especially when traveling to hot or dry places.  I also learned the value of flexibility and spontaneity.  On our last day at the beach, I had planned out a whole day of activities, but then we got caught up in a sudden rainstorm and had to change our plans.  It ended up being a really fun day, and we were able to make the most of the situation.  Instead of getting frustrated, we decided to go on a spontaneous adventure and explore the nearby woods.  It was a really great way to experience the area and make some wonderful memories.  I also learned the importance of trying new things and stepping out of my comfort zone.  On our trip, we tried some new foods and activities, and it was really rewarding to see how much fun I could have when I pushed myself to

STARTER: Do you play any sports or keep active? Have you joined any teams or tried something new lately?
text:
[Starter]: Do you play any sports or keep active? Have you joined any teams or tried something new lately?
[Student]: Or have you been at home asked Mary Van Vorst in a low voice and her father looked at him doubtfully for an answer with one of his usual rough words which he had made some time before by the childrens mother who had come up to the schoolhouse on Sunday afternoon to ask them questions about it during their absence from school when they were not coming homea long talk over which would be more than one could understand if she liked to hear anything that was said aloud together againwhen she suddenly remembered that Aunt Maria was there and that the teacher wanted to know where this story came fromher own particular chum and uncle to help her get back into the library and send Miss Holmes to a few days before the picnic And then all five turned to MrsMary Van Vorst as if afraid somebody might find out what that queer little fellow meant
[Teacher]: by saying he had been with the childrens mother on Sunday afternoon when the teacher looked at him doubtfully and he had just turned his back on her and had gone back to his seat in the back of the class so that nobody could see him and he was almost too busy to answer the teacher in his own words because he had his heart in his throat and his face was all flushed because of the thing that the teacher had said and he was afraid of the teacher and afraid of being found out and Mary and her friends were all laughing and talking and their voices were all very loud so that the children in the class did not hear what was said but the teacher did and she gave the boy a look of displeasure and the boy was afraid of her and he started to get up and go out of the class without waiting for the teacher to tell him to do so when the teacher stopped him and said I want to ask you something about the story you told me a little while ago and the boy hesitated and looked around at his friends and they were all whispering to him and he was afraid of what they might say and he started to tell the story all over again which was much the same as the first time except that he said a little more
[Student]: importantly to Uncle Ruthven and now he cant remember whether that boy was telling right away or not but he was only making sure there wasnt anybody else but the older ones were making sure that everybody knew how to guess everything until they were sure things were wrong and all that is true is to make sure no matter what happened afterward The lady laughed and Mary Van Vorst nodded to another member of the crowd and then the rest of the group gathered around a table that was spread on a corner of the room near the hall where Mr Hasnips office stood and Captain Jason stood looking down upon the assembled list of questions given to them by Mrs Gillooly Brown and the boys themselves who sat on the edge of the desk beside his chair opposite as they took breath under the teachers chair and drew forth a newspaper and read these two verses which he placed on each side of the page as followsin writing the book of commands written by Mary Van Vorst in order to give evidence against the powers that bereavement for an attempt at investigation through which she herself has already beguneach person who attempts to solve the most difficult task in any emergency is called in replythe captain or fireman who succeeds will
[Teacher]: get two hundred dollars and the winner of the contest will get a great reward which is to be given to the winner after the reading of the story of the mysterious disappearance of a certain young girl who was living in a house in a certain town with her mother and father and her older brother and sister who were all very much attached to her and who had been told not to visit her on the last night of her life because of a strange and painful experience which they had had with her and who had tried to get some of the money from the house that she had inherited from her grandfather and from the relatives who were going to pay her a visit the next day and they had been very much vexed with her for not giving them the money and they had said she was no good and no use and that she was a burden and a trouble and that they would be glad if she were out of the way because she was very much attached to her family and had a great many friends and was a good girl and had been very much loved by all who knew her and who had been told of her death and who had been very much grieved by her loss and who had written letters to the family to tell them of their grief and to say that they would

STARTER: Do you have any pets? How long have you had them, and what do you like most about them?
text:
[Starter]: Do you have any pets? How long have you had them, and what do you like most about them?
[Student]: Is it a puppy or an elephant He looked at his watch in the corner of her eyebrows and he put up her finger as if to say How dare I She shook her head sadly and said very harshly You wouldnt touch em but me Then she took him by the arm and held him back with one hand while they were talking together over and over again until their mother called them away from home where she had taken such good care of him that they went out on a long journey for many miles on foot through forests and down the country looking more beautiful than ever before when he first walked along the road with her kittens and was just crossing one of those fine old trees with green leaves under which he could see all the flowers he wanted to see and hear how he had come there once or twice every day and had always been so delighted with everything except his kitten and how clever its feet would be even then
[Teacher]: as he was just about to be put to sleep in his bed at night and it was very difficult to get him to sleep because of that kitten he had always had it with him and it was very difficult to keep him from running away and it was very difficult to keep him from doing so many other things that he would do which would get him into trouble and he was very fond of playing and running and jumping and climbing trees and chasing his kitten and laughing and having fun and being happy and being full of joy and being loved and being happy and being full of joy and being loved and being happy and being full of joy and being loved. and when he was old he went to the party and danced with the lady who was there who was so kind to him and he felt happy and full of joy and being loved and being full of joy and being loved and being happy and being full of joy and being loved. It is not the first time that such a story has been told and yet it is still a story that I am happy to tell. and there is no reason why I shouldnt tell it because I am the one who is happy to tell it and I am the one who am happy to tell it because I have experienced it and because

[Teacher]: Prince Edward in 1829 after which she died of consumption in 1861 and was succeeded by her husband and children and then her daughter married King George IV in 1830 and then King George IV died of a fever in 1830 and then King George IVs daughter married Prince Albert in 1839 and then Prince Albert died of typhoid fever in 1861 and then his daughter married King Leopold in 1862 and then the daughter of King Leopold died in 1880 and then King Leopold died of cancer in 1889 and then his daughter married King Leopold III in 1889 and then the son of King Leopold married King Leopold IIIs sister and then King Leopold III married King Leopolds sister in 1879 and then King Leopold III died of cancer in 1889 and then his daughter married King Leopold III in 1889 and then King Leopold III died of cancer in 1889 and then his daughter married King Leopold III in 1889 and then King Leopold III died of cancer in 1889 and then his daughter married King Leopold III in 1889 and

STARTER: Do you have any pets? How long have you had them, and what do you like most about them?
text:
[Starter]: Do you have any pets? How long have you had them, and what do you like most about them?
[Student]: Have they not been to the cemetery this morning asked Ruth with a smile which seemed to be taking a moment at their eagerness to get rid of her own curiosity in regard to Julias families so much as she knew how she longed for such a number of pretty little girls
[Teacher]: to be at her house as soon as possible.  Heathcliff took the letter from her hand and glanced over his shoulder at the figure walking away, before his eyes dropped to the page and he felt a strange sense of disquiet. The words on the page were written in familiar handwriting, but the subject matter sent a shiver down his spine.  Catherine had been dead for five years, but the letter from her was still as potent as ever, stirring up feelings he had thought were long buried. He felt a surge of anger and resentment towards the writer, whoever they were, but also a deep sense of sadness and longing.  Heathcliff's eyes scanned the page, his mind racing with questions. Who was writing to him? What did they want from him? And what was their connection to Catherine?  As he read on, his expression grew darker, his jaw clenched in a mixture of anger and pain. He felt like he was being pulled back into a world he thought he had left behind, a world of love and loss and heartache.  Heathcliff crumpled the letter in his hand, his heart heavy with emotion. He knew he had to confront whoever was writing to him, to find out what
[Student]: it meant that perhaps some one might say or act as though she could not possibly feel sure
[Teacher]: of her decision.  He was still wandering on when he came to a clearing in the woods, and as he emerged from the trees he saw a young woman sitting on a rock, her back to him.  She was dressed in a long, flowing cloak, and her hair was braided down her back like a ribbon.  Heathcliff's heart skipped a beat as he realized it was the woman from the letter.  He approached her quietly, not wanting to startle her, and as he drew near he saw that she was sitting in stillness, her eyes closed as if lost in thought.  He felt a sense of trepidation as he reached her side, his hand hesitating over hers.  She slowly turned her head, her eyes opening to meet his, and Heathcliff felt a jolt of electricity run through his body.  They stood there for a moment, looking at each other, as if time had stopped.  Heathcliff felt like he was seeing her for the first time, really seeing her, and he was struck by the beauty of her face, the depth of her eyes.  He felt a sense of wonder, of awe, as he gazed at her, and he knew

They stood there for a moment, looking at each other, as if time had stopped.  Heathcliff felt like he was seeing her for the first time, really seeing her, and he was struck by the beauty of her face, the depth of her eyes.  He felt a sense of wonder, of awe, as he gazed at her, and he knew

STARTER: Do you enjoy cooking at home? What's the best meal you've made recently, or do you prefer eating out?
text:
[Starter]: Do you enjoy cooking at home? What's the best meal you've made recently, or do you prefer eating out?
[Student]: The best
[Teacher]: part about cooking at home is the flexibility and control over the ingredients and flavors. When I'm cooking at home, I love being able to experiment with new recipes and ingredients to create dishes that are tailored to my taste preferences. Here, I'll outline some of the benefits of cooking at home and provide a simple recipe for you to try at home. **Benefits of cooking at home:**  1.  **Cost-effective:** Cooking at home can be more budget-friendly than eating out, as you can purchase ingredients in bulk and use leftovers to create new meals. 2.  **Healthier options:** When you cook at home, you have more control over the ingredients and portion sizes, making it easier to create healthier meals. 3.  **Flexibility:** Cooking at home allows you to experiment with new recipes and ingredients, making mealtime more enjoyable and exciting. 4.  **Quality time:** Cooking at home provides an opportunity to spend quality time with family and friends, sharing meals and creating memories.  Here's a simple recipe to try at home:  **Roasted Chicken and Vegetables**  Ingredients:  *   1 whole chicken (3-4 lbs) *   2 tbsp olive oil *   1 tsp salt *
[Student]: 2 teasingly flour 3 yams of bacon 5 parsley potatoes and onion leaves a plate that has been roasted before Christmas
[Teacher]: 1-2 garlic cloves *   2 tbsp lemon juice *   1 tsp dried thyme 1 tsp dried rosemary 1 tsp paprika 1 tsp salt 1/2 tsp black pepper 1/4 cup chicken broth 1/4 cup water 1/4 cup white wine (optional) Preheat the oven to 425°F (220°C).  Rinse the chicken and pat it dry with paper towels.  In a small bowl, mix together the olive oil, salt, pepper, thyme, rosemary, paprika, and garlic.  Rub the mixture all over the chicken, making sure to get some under the skin as well.  Place the chicken in a roasting pan and roast for 45-50 minutes, or until the internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C).  While the chicken is cooking, toss the yams, bacon, potatoes, and onion with the olive oil, salt, and pepper on a separate baking sheet.  Roast in the oven for 20-25 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender and lightly browned.  Remove the chicken from the oven and let it rest for 10 minutes before carving.  Serve with the roasted

1-2 garlic cloves *   2 tbsp lemon juice *   1 tsp dried thyme 1 tsp dried rosemary 1 tsp paprika 1 tsp salt 1/2 tsp black pepper 1/4 cup chicken broth 1/4 cup water 1/4 cup white wine (optional) Preheat the oven to 425°F (220°C). Rub the mixture all over the chicken, making sure to get some under the skin as well.  Place the chicken in a roasting pan and roast for 45-50 minutes, or until the internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C).  While the chicken is cooking, toss the yams, bacon, potatoes, and onion with the olive oil, salt, and pepper on a separate baking sheet.  Roast in the oven for 20-25 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender and lightly browned.  Remove the chicken from the oven and let it rest for 10 minutes before carving.  Serve with the roasted

STARTER: Do you celebrate any holidays with your family? Are there any special traditions or funny stories from past celebrations?
text:
[Starter]: Do you celebrate any holidays with your family? Are there any special traditions or funny stories from past celebrations?
[Student]: Your father is an old man and his wife is dead
[Teacher]: . He is a kind and generous man, but I are not sure if he's ready to celebrate a big family gathering due to his grief. I want to get him involved in a family tradition but not put too much pressure on him.   1. Consider his feelings: Understand that your father is still grieving the loss of his wife and may not be ready or willing to celebrate big family gatherings. Be sensitive to his feelings and boundaries.   2. Start small: Begin with low-key celebrations or smaller gatherings, such as a quiet dinner or a family movie night. This can help him feel more comfortable and build confidence in participating in family celebrations.   3. Involve him in planning: Ask your father to help plan a small celebration or activity, such as choosing a recipe or picking out a movie. This can help him feel more invested and engaged in the celebration.   4. Focus on memories: Create a special memory book or scrapbook with pictures and stories from past celebrations. This can help your father feel more connected to his family and the tradition.   5. Be patient: Don't rush your father into celebrating big family gatherings. Let him set the pace and pace himself.   6. Find a

[Teacher]: for a birthday celebration.   7. Get him to help you: Involve your father in planning a celebration, and ask him to help you pick out decorations, choose a menu, or select a gift. This can help him feel more involved and invested in the celebration.   8. Have fun: Celebrate in your own way and have fun with your father. Don't put too much pressure on the celebration, and enjoy the time you spend together.   9. Be mindful of his comfort level: Pay attention to your father's comfort level and boundaries. If he seems uncomfortable or hesitant, it's okay to slow down or take a break.   10.  **Consider having a family gathering without him.**   If your father is not feeling up to celebrating, it's okay to have a family gathering without him. This can be a good opportunity to connect with other family members and create new memories without putting pressure on your father.   11.  **Involve him in small ways**: Even if your father can't participate in a big family gathering, he can still be involved in small ways, such as sending a card or helping with a small activity.   12.  **Find a way
